Sentences: Good afternoon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thanks for joining us today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would like to begin by acknowledging the tragic loss and tremendous hardship that people are experiencing both here in the United States and around the world.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The coronavirus outbreak is first and foremost a public health crisis, and the most important response is coming from those in the front lines in hospitals, emergency services, and care facilities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: On behalf of the Federal Reserve, let me express our sincere gratitude to those dedicated individuals who put themselves at risk, day after day, in service to others and to our nation.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The forceful measures that we as a country are taking to control the spread of the virus have brought much of the economy to an abrupt halt.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many businesses have closed, people have been asked to stay home, and basic social interactions are greatly curtailed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: People are putting their lives and livelihoods on hold, at significant economic and personal cost.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: All of us are affected, but the burdens are falling most heavily on those least able to carry them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It is worth remembering that the measures we are taking to contain the virus represent an investment in our individual and collective health.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As a society, we should do everything we can to provide relief to those who are suffering for the public good.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While many standard economic statistics have yet to catch up with the reality we’re experiencing, it’s clear that the effects on the economy are severe.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Millions of workers are losing their jobs:  Next week’s jobs report is expected to show that the unemployment rate, which was at 50-year lows just two months ago, has surged into double digits.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Household spending has plummeted as people stay home, and measures of consumer sentiment have fallen precipitously.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Hotels, airlines, restaurants, department stores, and other retailers have been particularly hard hit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Manufacturing output fell sharply in March and is likely to drop even more likely drop at an unprecedented rate in the second quarter.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Inflation is also being held down, reflecting weaker demand as well as significantly lower energy prices.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Both the depth and the duration of the economic downturn are extraordinarily uncertain and will depend in large part on how quickly the virus is brought under control.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The severity of the downturn will also depend on the policy actions taken at all levels of government to cushion the blow and to support the recovery when the public health crisis passes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Federal Reserve’s response is guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people, along with our responsibilities to promote the stability of the financial system.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are also committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy in this challenging time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Last month we quickly lowered our policy interest rate to near zero.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We stated then and again today that we expect to maintain interest rates at this level until we’re confident that the economy has weathered recent events and is on track to achieve our maximum-employment and price-stability goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, lowering interest rates cannot stop the sharp drop in economic activity caused by closures and other forms of social distancing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And low rates will not effectively spur the economy if those rates do not feed through to broader financial conditions or if households and businesses are unable to get credit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The economic disruptions caused by the virus created tremendous strains in some essential financial markets and have impaired the flow of credit in the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Without access to credit, families can be forced to cut back on necessities and could lose their homes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Businesses can be forced to downsize or close, resulting in further losses of jobs and incomes and worsening the downturn.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Preserving the flow of credit is thus essential for mitigating the forceful actions to these ends.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: To support the flow of credit to households and businesses, foster smooth market functioning, and promote effective transmission of monetary policy to broader financial conditions, we have been purchasing large amounts of Treasury and agency mortgage-backed securities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The markets for these securities play a critical role in the economy, and they came under great stress last month as the scale of economic disruption became clearer and as investors clamored for liquidity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Our purchases have helped market conditions improve substantially in recent weeks.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In light of this improvement, we have slowed our pace of purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will continue our purchases of Treasury and agency mortgage-backed securities as needed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: While the primary purpose of these securities purchases is to preserve smooth market functioning and effective policy transmission, the purchases will offer—will also foster more accommodative financial conditions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are also undertaking programs to provide stability to the financial system and to more directly support the flow of credit in the economy—for households, for businesses of all sizes, and for state and local governments.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: These programs benefit the economy by providing financing where it is not otherwise available.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, by serving as a backstop to key credit markets, the programs can improve market functioning by increasing the willingness of private lenders to extend credit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many of these programs rely on emergency lending powers that are available only in very unusual circumstances, such as those we find ourselves in today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We are deploying these lending powers to an unprecedented extent, enabled in large part by the financial backing and support from Congress and the Treasury.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will continue to use these powers recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I would stress that these are lending powers and not spending powers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Fed cannot grant money to particular beneficiaries.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can only make loans to solvent entities that the—with the expectation that the loans will be repaid.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Many borrowers will benefit from our programs, as will the overall economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But for many others, getting a loan that may be difficult to repay may not be the answer.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In these cases, direct fiscal support may be needed.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Elected officials have the power to tax and spend and to make decisions about where we, as a society, should direct our collective resources.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The Cares Act and other legislation provide direct help to people, businesses, and communities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This direct support can make a critical difference not just in helping families and businesses in a time of need, but also in limiting long-lasting damage to our economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: At the Fed, we’re doing all we can to help American families and businesses weather this difficult period.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: When the spread of the virus is under control, businesses will reopen, and people will come back to work.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will continue to use our tools to assure that the recovery, when it comes, will be as robust as possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Thank you, and I’ll be glad to take your questions.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Jeanna Smialek.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: Thanks for taking our questions.
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: You guys have cut rates to zero, you’re buying up huge quantities of government debt—I guess the question is, what more can you realistically do to help the economy, and where do you see a need for Congress to step in?
Speaker: JEANNA SMIALEK.

Sentences: So let me say that we’re—we’re committed to using our full range of tools to support the economy in this challenging time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to use them, as I mentioned, recovery and also to assure that that recovery, when it comes, will be as robust as possible.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As long as needed, we’ll use them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I would just say, we have a number of dimensions on which we can still provide support to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As you know, our credit policies are not subject to a specific dollar limit.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They can be expanded as appropriate, and we can do new ones.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we can continue to be part of the answer.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Will there be a need to do more, though?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think the answer to that—that will be “yes.”  I would say, Congress has also reacted quite aggressively and strongly with the Cares Act and other laws—several other laws.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And that’s appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With enhanced unemployment insurance and the Paycheck Protection Program, we’ve seen an extraordinary, historically large reaction.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I would say that it may well be the case that the economy will need more support from all of us if the—if the recovery is to be a robust one.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nick Timiraos.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thanks, Chair Powell.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: Nick Timiraos of the Wall Street Journal.
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: I want to follow up on Jeanna’s question and ask, what specifically do you think elected officials should consider in order to help return or hasten a stronger return to full employment?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: And what policy tools did you discuss at your meeting today that might be used to stop a deflationary spiral?
Speaker: NICK TIMIRAOS.

Sentences: So let me—let me start—I’ll take the questions in the order you—you gave them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So in terms of, if I can say, legislative priorities, we don’t—we’re not responsible for fiscal policy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Those will be decisions for Congress to make.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But I would say that policies that protect workers, businesses, and households from avoidable insolvency, that keep businesses going so that they’re able to produce goods and—and to either hold on to their price tag, but we would come out of this event eventually with—with a stronger economy and with less long-run damage to the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s—that’s a key thing that—that, really, Congress could do over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of what we can do, I mentioned, we have our—our credit facilities are—are wide open.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can do more on that front.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In addition, you know, we’ve had—we’ve had extensive discussions, as I’ve mentioned—done a lot of thinking about what monetary policy might look like over—in coming months over a range of potential scenarios for the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We do think that our—our policy stance today is right where it should be for now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As you know, we cut rates to the effective lower bound, we—and we’ve said that we’ll keep them there until we’re confident that the economy has weathered the effects of the outbreak and is on track to achieve our goals.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: With asset purchases, we’re continuing to purchase Treasury securities and agency MBS in the amounts needed to support smooth market functioning.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’re doing those things, and I would say that we’ll continue to use our tools as needs be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Steve Liesman.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Mr. Chairman, question—Steve Liesman with CNBC.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: I’ve got two questions here.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: First of all, why aren’t you announcing or conducting a specific quantitative easing program?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: And—and maybe you could explain what the context is now of the purchases that will be made and the amounts that are to come.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: The second question I have is, are—is the Federal Reserve really taking enough risk to help households and businesses here, in that you just said that the programs that are out there may be best for those who are able to repay loans.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: But—so don’t you have a series of programs it the least?
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: Thank you.
Speaker: STEVE LIESMAN.

Sentences: So, let me say again, in terms of—of asset purchases and—and other measures, we—we do think our—our policy stance is appropriate now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve had discussions, as I’ve mentioned, over time and done quite a bit of thinking about what we might do in the future.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think, for now, our policy stance is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re not going to change it now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we’re really waiting to see more from the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: There are a range of potential paths the economy could be on, and I think as—as the time approaches for—then we’ll—you know, we’ll address your first question, which is about asset purchases.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So—but that’s not something we’re doing today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s—it’s something that we have talked about, and, you know, for now, we like our current policy stance.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of risk, so, you know, we operate under the laws that Congress passes.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And there are a number of aspects under section 13(3), and you can see that they’ve permitted us to, I think, move very quickly and move into areas where we’ve never been before and do so quite aggressively.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I—I think we’re going places and providing help in places where we never have, and I’m glad that we are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think it’s appropriate that we are.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Nonetheless, these are lending powers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And if you read section 13(3) of the Dodd-Frank—or, the Federal Reserve Act, and I know you have, it does require that—that we be secured to our satisfaction, and—and we can’t lend to insolvent companies.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: You know, it’s clear these are lending powers, and we are—we are ultimately bound to—to implement the laws that Congress gives us.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We—we do not make grants.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We can’t make grants.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I—the reason I raised that in my remarks is that I just want to be clear on that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: those powers.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will—we’ll keep at it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And you—I just want people to know that we’ll—we will be at it with—with the legal authorities that we have until we get through this thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We will keep using our authorities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But there are authorities that we don’t have, and there may be a need for those authorities to be used as well as ours.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Heather Long.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Hi.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: Hi, Chair Powell, it’s Heather Long from the Washington Post.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: I have two questions for you, both on timing.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: The first, do you plan to launch the Corporate Credit Facility and the Main Street lending facilities in May or early May?
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: Anything you can give us—a sense on timing?
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: And the second, in the statement, you referred today—the FOMC refers today to a lot of medium-term risks from the pandemic.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: That sounds like you all think this is going to be a long recovery—a long road to recovery.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: Can you give any more guidance on how you all see this recovery taking shape?
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: Thanks.
Speaker: HEATHER LONG.

Sentences: Sure.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, in terms of those facilities, the corporate credit facilities are near being finalized and will be operating, I would say, soon—fairly soon.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Main Street facility is—we’re close to announcing—to issuing a new term sheet.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: As you know, we put out a term sheet for comment a while back, and we got a couple thousand comments.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve carefully studied them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve tried to reflect those in what we’re doing now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I think, with Main Street, there’ll be at least a couple of different kinds of lending going on there.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It—this is a broad area of the economy with many different kinds of credit needs, so we’re going to keep at that for some time, I think, adding in sectors and lending products.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So I think we’ll be at—we’ll as quickly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But the first part of it, I think, will be done fairly quickly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: In terms of our statement, so what we said was that we—I’ll just read the sentence.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It says:  “[The] ongoing public health crisis will weigh heavily on economic activity, employment, and inflation in the near term and poses considerable risks to the economic outlook over the medium term.”  So the “medium”—but what we meant by that, “over the medium term”—so, obviously, what we’re talking about is, you know, not right now, in the very near term.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’s between now and the long term, so the next year or so.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And I would point to a couple of—of risks to the outlook that—what we were thinking of.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: First is just the virus.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: How long will it take to get it under control?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Will there be additional outbreaks?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Will there be drugs that can either treat it or—or a vaccine of some kind?
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So there’s—all of that is very much shrouded in uncertainty.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The second issue—and this is a very substantial one—is just the possibility of—of damage to the productive capacity of the economy through a couple of channels.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The first is just workers who—if one is unemployed for an extended period, that person can—can lose the skills that are needed, can lose touch with the labor force, and have difficulty restarting his or her career.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s a—that’s a feature of deep and long recessions, and that’s something we’ve got to watch out for.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Another is just businesses—you know, these thousands of great medium- and small-sized businesses that we have all over the country.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They’re worth so much more to the economy than the sum of their net assets.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: They contain—you know, they’re job creators, they’re really important.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And if we see an unnecessary—unnecessary insolvencies, a wave of those, that could be damaging to the performance of the economy over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So the good news is that we not perfectly.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s—that’s another risk.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The third thing I would point to is just the global dimension.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: This is a very global phenomenon, and you are—we’re seeing economic data from around the globe which is very, very negative, and that, too, can weigh on U.S. economic performance over time.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I—you know, I would say, just on the U.S.—on the U.S. economy, there are things you can say, one can say.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The first is that, in the near term, we’re going to see, you know, significant declines in economic activity, significant declines in employment, and increases in unemployment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to see that as a consequence of the virus and the measures we’re taking to protect ourselves from it.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: The next phases are more uncertain, highly uncertain, but we will go through a phase starting fairly soon where we begin to reopen the economy.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And probably the economic activity will pick up as consumer spending picks up.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Consumer spending, as I mentioned, has gone down quite a lot.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: It’ll begin to pick up as people start to return to their normal patterns of spending.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: But the chances are that it won’t go right back to where we were, because people will—until they’re confident of—that the virus is well and truly under control, then they will be somewhat probably reluctant to—to undertake certain kinds of activity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it may take some time for us to get back—it probably will take some time for us to get back to—you know, to a more normal level of unemployment and—and, ultimately, to maximum employment.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Okay, James Politi.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Thanks, Chair Powell.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: You didn’t firm up your guidance on—this is James Politi from the Financial Times—you didn’t firm up your guidance on interest rates at this meeting.
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: And given the risks that you just outlined, under what circumstances would you strengthen the Fed’s commitment to keep rates at the lower bound?
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: And is there any danger to expecting for the programs that were set up under the Cares Act, and are you expecting them to rapidly reach capacity like the PPP plan did?
Speaker: JAMES POLITI.

Sentences: Okay.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So on the first, as I mentioned, you know, we moved very quickly, very aggressively.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We were the first to return to the effective lower bound, where we are now.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We got there essentially right away, and we think that’s the right place to be.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We think, if you look at surveys, you look at market pricing, the market expects us to—to be there for a good while, and that’s appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So, you know, it’s not as though the market is pricing in a near-term liftoff or anything like that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And let me just say, we’re going to not be in any hurry to withdraw these measures or to lift off.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’re going to wait until we’re—we’re quite confident that the economy is—is well on the road to recovery.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we don’t see—we see our current stance and our current guidance—and I would say the same thing about asset purchases—we see them as appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: I’ve—I’ve also mentioned now a couple times that we have done a lot of thinking about what monetary policy might look like over coming months, and that would, you know, depend on—on where we are in—in a range of potential economic scenarios.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we—we were thinking about that all the time, but right now, for now, we think our current stance is appropriate.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we made no change in it today.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Second question was, how—so the thing about our facilities is, Treasury still has plenty of equity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we’ve said that if—if demand for our facilities is greater than we’ve estimated, then we’ll expand them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we have the ability to do that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So it won’t be the way the—the Paycheck Protection Program is, where there’s a specific amount allocated—appropriated for it, and—and then there’s no more money.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: That’s—that will be unlikely to happen here unless we exhaust Treasury’s equity, and we’re a long way from doing that.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: facilities—and I mentioned this in my remarks—it’s not just the actual lending we do, it’s the—we build confidence in the market.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And private market participants come in.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And many companies that would’ve had to come to the Fed have now been able to finance themselves privately since we announced the—the initial term sheet on—on these facilities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So that’s a good thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Companies are out there financing, they’re out there raising liquidity.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We haven’t made any corporate loans to—in those facilities.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: We’ve made the short-term money market loans, but—we haven’t made any of them.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And yet there’s a tremendous amount of financing going on, and that’s a good thing.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: So we—for that reason, the ultimate demand for the facilities is quite difficult to predict, because there is this announcement effect that really gets the market functioning again.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Of course, we have to follow through, though.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: And we will follow through to validate that—that announcement effect.
Speaker: CHAIR POWELL.

Sentences: Okay, Howard Schneider.
Speaker: MICHELLE SMITH.

Sentences: Oh, hi, Chair Powell, and thanks for doing this.
Speaker: HOWARD SCHNEIDER.
